rb_notes.editor:
{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Init State Description"},{"insert":"

The init state indicates that a router sees HELLO packets from the neighbor, but two-way communication has not been established. A Cisco router includes the Router IDs of all neighbors in the init (or higher) state in the Neighbor field of its HELLO packets. For two-way communication to be established with a neighbor, a router also must see its own Router ID in the Neighbor field of the neighbor's HELLO packets. 
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Troubleshoot INIT State Flow Chart:"},{"insert":"

"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Map:"},{"insert":"
1. Checking Network Type
	These values will be collected:
Interface Network-type"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
2. Checking OSPF Interface Authentication
	These values will be collected:
Interface Authentication"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
3. Checking ACL List on OSPF Link
	These values will be collected:
Access List on OSPF Interface"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Init State Description

The init state indicates that a router sees HELLO packets from the neighbor, but two-way communication has not been established. A Cisco router includes the Router IDs of all neighbors in the init (or higher) state in the Neighbor field of its HELLO packets. For two-way communication to be established with a neighbor, a router also must see its own Router ID in the Neighbor field of the neighbor's HELLO packets. 
 
Troubleshoot INIT State Flow Chart:

Map:
1. Checking Network Type
	These values will be collected:
Interface Network-type
 
2. Checking OSPF Interface Authentication
	These values will be collected:
Interface Authentication
 
3. Checking ACL List on OSPF Link
	These values will be collected:
Access List on OSPF Interface

{"ops":[{"insert":"
When OSPF adjacency is formed, a router goes through several state changes before it becomes fully adjacent with its neighbor. Those states are defined in the OSPF RFC 2328, section 10.1. The states are Down, Attempt, Init, 2-Way, Exstart, Exchange, Loading, and Full. 

This runbook is to troubleshoot multiple OPPF states with details. 
1: Retrieve relevant OSPF CLI Commands
2: Monitor OSPF Neighbors
3: Retrive OSPF CLI Commands
4: Select One or More Activities
5-1: Troubleshoot OSPF Neighbor Not Established 
5-2: Troubleshoot OSPF Neighbor INIT State 
5-3: Troubleshoot OSPF Neighbor Two-Way State
5-4: Troubleshoot OSPF Neighbor Exstart or Exchange State 
5-5: Troubleshoot OSPF Neighbor Loading State

References:

When OSPF adjacency is formed, a router goes through several state changes before it becomes fully adjacent with its neighbor. Those states are defined in the OSPF RFC 2328, section 10.1. The states are Down, Attempt, Init, 2-Way, Exstart, Exchange, Loading, and Full. 

This runbook is to troubleshoot multiple OPPF states with details. 
1: Retrieve relevant OSPF CLI Commands

rb_notes.editor:
{"ops":[{"insert":" 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Check Link State Request Packets:"},{"insert":"
 
In the loading state, routers send link-state request packets. During the adjacency, if a router receives an outdated or missing link-state advertisement (LSA), it requests that LSA by sending a link-state request packet. This problem could be possibly caused by OSPF ospf link quality. Please check the interfaces.

"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Recommend CLI Commands:"},{"insert":"
	The output from the following commands:
	1) Cisco Router,Cisco IOS Switch:
show interface"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Check Link State Request Packets:
 
In the loading state, routers send link-state request packets. During the adjacency, if a router receives an outdated or missing link-state advertisement (LSA), it requests that LSA by sending a link-state request packet. This problem could be possibly caused by OSPF ospf link quality. Please check the interfaces.

Recommend CLI Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
	1) Cisco Router,Cisco IOS Switch:
show interface

rb_notes.editor:
{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"No State Revealed Description"},{"insert":"

If the show ip ospf neighbor command reveals nothing at all - or reveals nothing about the particular neighbor you are analyzing - then this router has not seen any "valid" OSPF HELLOs from that neighbor. This means that OSPF either did not receive any HELLO packets from the neighbor or received HELLO packets that failed very basic sanity checks.
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Troubleshoot No State Revealed Flow Chart:"},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":" "},{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Ping:"},{"insert":"
1. Checking for IP connectivity between the neighbor routers
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Map:"},{"insert":"
2. Verifying if Interface Sends/Receives HELLO Packets
	These values will be collected:
Interface Status"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"OSPF Router-ID"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"OSPF Passive Interface"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
3. Verifying if HELLO Parameters Match
	These values will be collected:
Hello Dead-Interval"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"Process ID"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"Area ID"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
No State Revealed Description

If the show ip ospf neighbor command reveals nothing at all - or reveals nothing about the particular neighbor you are analyzing - then this router has not seen any "valid" OSPF HELLOs from that neighbor. This means that OSPF either did not receive any HELLO packets from the neighbor or received HELLO packets that failed very basic sanity checks.
 
Troubleshoot No State Revealed Flow Chart:
 
Ping:
1. Checking for IP connectivity between the neighbor routers
 
Map:
2. Verifying if Interface Sends/Receives HELLO Packets
	These values will be collected:
Interface Status
OSPF Router-ID
OSPF Passive Interface
 
3. Verifying if HELLO Parameters Match
	These values will be collected:
Hello Dead-Interval
Process ID
Area ID

                                               R4                                    R5
  170.170.3.0/24______________I__________________I_____________

{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Init State Description"},{"insert":"

The init state indicates that a router sees HELLO packets from the neighbor, but two-way communication has not been established. A Cisco router includes the Router IDs of all neighbors in the init (or higher) state in the Neighbor field of its HELLO packets. For two-way communication to be established with a neighbor, a router also must see its own Router ID in the Neighbor field of the neighbor's HELLO packets. 
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Troubleshoot INIT State Flow Chart:"},{"insert":"

rb_notes.text:
Init State Description

The init state indicates that a router sees HELLO packets from the neighbor, but two-way communication has not been established. A Cisco router includes the Router IDs of all neighbors in the init (or higher) state in the Neighbor field of its HELLO packets. For two-way communication to be established with a neighbor, a router also must see its own Router ID in the Neighbor field of the neighbor's HELLO packets. 
 
Troubleshoot INIT State Flow Chart:

Map:
1. Checking Network Type
	These values will be collected:
Interface Network-type
 
2. Checking OSPF Interface Authentication
	These values will be collected:
Interface Authentication
 
3. Checking ACL List on OSPF Link
	These values will be collected:
Access List on OSPF Interface

rb_notes.editor:
{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Exstart/Exchange State Description"},{"insert":"

Neighbor in exstart or exchange State
   SPF neighbors that are in exstart or exchange state are trying to exchange DBD packets. The router and its neighbor form a master and slave relationship. The adjacency should continue past this state. If it does not, there is a problem with the DBD exchange, such as a maximum transmission unit (MTU) mismatch or the receipt of an unexpected DBD sequence number. 
 
Exstart State
   After two OSPF neighboring routers establish bi-directional communication and complete DR/BDR election (on multi-access networks), the routers transition to the exstart state. In this state, the neighboring routers establish a master/slave relationship and determine the initial database descriptor (DBD) sequence number to use while exchanging DBD packets.
 
Exchange State
   Once the master/slave relationship has been negotiated (the router with the highest Router-ID becomes the master), the neighboring routers transition into the exchange state. In this state, the routers exchange DBD packets, which describe their entire link-state database. The routers also send link-state request packets, which request more recent link-state advertisements (LSA) from neighbors.
 
Although OSPF neighbors transition through the exstart/exchange states during the normal OSPF adjacency-building process, it is not normal for OSPF neighbors to be stuck in this state. 
 
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Troubleshoot Exstart/Exchange State Flow Chart:"},{"insert":"
 
1. The Problem on Layer 2 
To determine if the problem is a layer 2 problem, checking if a proxy ARP is enabled. If it s enabled, then disable it and use the  clear ip arp  command to clear the ARP cache."},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
2. Check OSPF Link MTU
	These values will be collected:
IP MTU"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
3. Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
Ping"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
4. Check Neighbor over PRI
if neighbors connected via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type must be p2mp, please check the interface network-type."},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Exstart/Exchange State Description

Neighbor in exstart or exchange State
   SPF neighbors that are in exstart or exchange state are trying to exchange DBD packets. The router and its neighbor form a master and slave relationship. The adjacency should continue past this state. If it does not, there is a problem with the DBD exchange, such as a maximum transmission unit (MTU) mismatch or the receipt of an unexpected DBD sequence number. 
 
Exstart State
   After two OSPF neighboring routers establish bi-directional communication and complete DR/BDR election (on multi-access networks), the routers transition to the exstart state. In this state, the neighboring routers establish a master/slave relationship and determine the initial database descriptor (DBD) sequence number to use while exchanging DBD packets.
 
Exchange State
   Once the master/slave relationship has been negotiated (the router with the highest Router-ID becomes the master), the neighboring routers transition into the exchange state. In this state, the routers exchange DBD packets, which describe their entire link-state database. The routers also send link-state request packets, which request more recent link-state advertisements (LSA) from neighbors.
 
Although OSPF neighbors transition through the exstart/exchange states during the normal OSPF adjacency-building process, it is not normal for OSPF neighbors to be stuck in this state. 
 
 
Troubleshoot Exstart/Exchange State Flow Chart:
 
1. The Problem on Layer 2 
To determine if the problem is a layer 2 problem, checking if a proxy ARP is enabled. If it s enabled, then disable it and use the  clear ip arp  command to clear the ARP cache.
 
2. Check OSPF Link MTU
	These values will be collected:
IP MTU
 
3. Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
Ping
 
4. Check Neighbor over PRI
if neighbors connected via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type must be p2mp, please check the interface network-type.

{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc","bold":true},"insert":"Exstart/Exchange State Description"},{"insert":"

Neighbor in exstart or exchange State
   SPF neighbors that are in exstart or exchange state are trying to exchange DBD packets. The router and its neighbor form a master and slave relationship. The adjacency should continue past this state. If it does not, there is a problem with the DBD exchange, such as a maximum transmission unit (MTU) mismatch or the receipt of an unexpected DBD sequence number. 
 
Exstart State
   After two OSPF neighboring routers establish bi-directional communication and complete DR/BDR election (on multi-access networks), the routers transition to the exstart state. In this state, the neighboring routers establish a master/slave relationship and determine the initial database descriptor (DBD) sequence number to use while exchanging DBD packets.
 
Exchange State
   Once the master/slave relationship has been negotiated (the router with the highest Router-ID becomes the master), the neighboring routers transition into the exchange state. In this state, the routers exchange DBD packets, which describe their entire link-state database. The routers also send link-state request packets, which request more recent link-state advertisements (LSA) from neighbors.
 
Although OSPF neighbors transition through the exstart/exchange states during the normal OSPF adjacency-building process, it is not normal for OSPF neighbors to be stuck in this state. 
 
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc","bold":true},"insert":"Troubleshoot Exstart/Exchange State Flow Chart:"},{"insert":"
 
1. The Problem on Layer 2 
To determine if the problem is a layer 2 problem, checking if a proxy ARP is enabled. If it s enabled, then disable it and use the  clear ip arp  command to clear the ARP cache."},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
2. Check OSPF Link MTU
	These values will be collected:
IP MTU"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
3. Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
Ping"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
4. Check Neighbor over PRI
if neighbors connected via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type must be p2mp, please check the interface network-type."},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"}]}
rb_notes.text:
Exstart/Exchange State Description

Neighbor in exstart or exchange State
   SPF neighbors that are in exstart or exchange state are trying to exchange DBD packets. The router and its neighbor form a master and slave relationship. The adjacency should continue past this state. If it does not, there is a problem with the DBD exchange, such as a maximum transmission unit (MTU) mismatch or the receipt of an unexpected DBD sequence number. 
 
Exstart State
   After two OSPF neighboring routers establish bi-directional communication and complete DR/BDR election (on multi-access networks), the routers transition to the exstart state. In this state, the neighboring routers establish a master/slave relationship and determine the initial database descriptor (DBD) sequence number to use while exchanging DBD packets.
 
Exchange State
   Once the master/slave relationship has been negotiated (the router with the highest Router-ID becomes the master), the neighboring routers transition into the exchange state. In this state, the routers exchange DBD packets, which describe their entire link-state database. The routers also send link-state request packets, which request more recent link-state advertisements (LSA) from neighbors.
 
Although OSPF neighbors transition through the exstart/exchange states during the normal OSPF adjacency-building process, it is not normal for OSPF neighbors to be stuck in this state. 
 
 
Troubleshoot Exstart/Exchange State Flow Chart:
 
1. The Problem on Layer 2 
To determine if the problem is a layer 2 problem, checking if a proxy ARP is enabled. If it s enabled, then disable it and use the  clear ip arp  command to clear the ARP cache.
 
2. Check OSPF Link MTU
	These values will be collected:
IP MTU
 
3. Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
Ping
 
4. Check Neighbor over PRI
if neighbors connected via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type must be p2mp, please check the interface network-type.

"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Init State Description"},{"insert":"

The init state indicates that a router sees HELLO packets from the neighbor, but two-way communication has not been established. A Cisco router includes the Router IDs of all neighbors in the init (or higher) state in the Neighbor field of its HELLO packets. For two-way communication to be established with a neighbor, a router also must see its own Router ID in the Neighbor field of the neighbor's HELLO packets.

rb_notes.text:
Init State Description

The init state indicates that a router sees HELLO packets from the neighbor, but two-way communication has not been established. A Cisco router includes the Router IDs of all neighbors in the init (or higher) state in the Neighbor field of its HELLO packets. For two-way communication to be established with a neighbor, a router also must see its own Router ID in the Neighbor field of the neighbor's HELLO packets. 
 
Troubleshoot INIT State Flow Chart:

170.170.3.4   1   FULL/DROTHER  00:00:37   170.170.3.4       Ethernet0

rb_notes.editor:
{"ops":[{"insert":"
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Exstart/Exchange State Description"},{"insert":"

Neighbor in exstart or exchange State
   SPF neighbors that are in exstart or exchange state are trying to exchange DBD packets. The router and its neighbor form a master and slave relationship. The adjacency should continue past this state. If it does not, there is a problem with the DBD exchange, such as a maximum transmission unit (MTU) mismatch or the receipt of an unexpected DBD sequence number. 
 
Exstart State
   After two OSPF neighboring routers establish bi-directional communication and complete DR/BDR election (on multi-access networks), the routers transition to the exstart state. In this state, the neighboring routers establish a master/slave relationship and determine the initial database descriptor (DBD) sequence number to use while exchanging DBD packets.
 
Exchange State
   Once the master/slave relationship has been negotiated (the router with the highest Router-ID becomes the master), the neighboring routers transition into the exchange state. In this state, the routers exchange DBD packets, which describe their entire link-state database. The routers also send link-state request packets, which request more recent link-state advertisements (LSA) from neighbors.
 
Although OSPF neighbors transition through the exstart/exchange states during the normal OSPF adjacency-building process, it is not normal for OSPF neighbors to be stuck in this state. 
 
 
"},{"attributes":{"color":"#0066cc"},"insert":"Troubleshoot Exstart/Exchange State Flow Chart:"},{"insert":"
 
1. The Problem on Layer 2 
To determine if the problem is a layer 2 problem, checking if a proxy ARP is enabled. If it s enabled, then disable it and use the  clear ip arp  command to clear the ARP cache."},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
2. Check OSPF Link MTU
	These values will be collected:
IP MTU"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
3. Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
Ping"},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"
"},{"insert":" 
4. Check Neighbor over PRI
if neighbors connected via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type must be p2mp, please check the interface network-type."},{"attributes":{"list":"bullet"},"insert":"

rb_notes.text:
Exstart/Exchange State Description

Neighbor in exstart or exchange State
   SPF neighbors that are in exstart or exchange state are trying to exchange DBD packets. The router and its neighbor form a master and slave relationship. The adjacency should continue past this state. If it does not, there is a problem with the DBD exchange, such as a maximum transmission unit (MTU) mismatch or the receipt of an unexpected DBD sequence number. 
 
Exstart State
   After two OSPF neighboring routers establish bi-directional communication and complete DR/BDR election (on multi-access networks), the routers transition to the exstart state. In this state, the neighboring routers establish a master/slave relationship and determine the initial database descriptor (DBD) sequence number to use while exchanging DBD packets.
 
Exchange State
   Once the master/slave relationship has been negotiated (the router with the highest Router-ID becomes the master), the neighboring routers transition into the exchange state. In this state, the routers exchange DBD packets, which describe their entire link-state database. The routers also send link-state request packets, which request more recent link-state advertisements (LSA) from neighbors.
 
Although OSPF neighbors transition through the exstart/exchange states during the normal OSPF adjacency-building process, it is not normal for OSPF neighbors to be stuck in this state. 
 
 
Troubleshoot Exstart/Exchange State Flow Chart:
 
1. The Problem on Layer 2 
To determine if the problem is a layer 2 problem, checking if a proxy ARP is enabled. If it s enabled, then disable it and use the  clear ip arp  command to clear the ARP cache.
 
2. Check OSPF Link MTU
	These values will be collected:
IP MTU
 
3. Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
Ping
 
4. Check Neighbor over PRI
if neighbors connected via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type must be p2mp, please check the interface network-type.

rb_notes.nodeName: 5.4.3 Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
rb_notes.text:
If you can t ping the neighbor interface IP addresses with a large ping packet, the problem could be related to layer 2 not passing large packets, then check cabling and hubs.
	 
Related Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
		1) ping {OSPF Neighbors IP Address}

rb_notes.text:
Check Neighor over PRI

If neighbors connect via PRI/BRI Link, the OSPF network type is p2mp. Please check the interface network-type.
 
Recommend CLI Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
	1) Cisco Router,Cisco IOS Switch:
show ip ospf interface
show interface

rb_notes.nodeName: 5.4.3 Ping Neighboring IP with a Large Parket
rb_notes.text:
If you can t ping the neighbor interface IP addresses with a large ping packet, the problem could be related to layer 2 not passing large packets, then check cabling and hubs.
	 
Related Commands:
	The output from the following commands:
		1) ping {OSPF Neighbors IP Address}
